title: More than 4,000 patients had their life-saving surgeries cancelled at the last minute due to lack of beds and staff
text:
Many urgent operations have had to be shelved because hospitals are under-resourced (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A record number of NHS patients are having their cancer operations and other life-saving surgery axed at the last minute. 
Figures reveal a 27% increase in two years in the number of urgent operations cancelled by overstretched hospitals. 
NHS England said 4,093 urgent ­operations were cancelled in 2016, due to a lack of beds or staff. The number was 3,216 in 2014. 
The data also revealed that 145 urgent operations were cancelled twice or more in 2016 – also the highest on record. In 2011, the figure was just 65. 
Labour’s Shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworth said: “Theresa May’s NHS crisis continues, and the problems are worse and more widespread than in previous years. By underfunding and overstretching the NHS, the Tories have pushed health services to the brink.” Read More Surgeons furious at NHS 'cost-cutting' plans to ration hip and knee replacements The number of ops that have been cancelled has increased by 27 per cent (Photo: Getty) 
Lib Dem Health Spokesman Norman Lamb said: “The Government’s stubborn refusal to give the NHS emergency funding means record numbers of operations are being cancelled as hospitals face weeks on end of intolerable pressure. 
“This is no longer a winter crisis, it’s a winter catastrophe.” 
An urgent operation is defined as one that is life-saving, which is needed to save a limb or organ, or where a patient is at risk of dying if their condition is allowed to deteriorate. It can include cancer patients and those needing heart surgery. 
A Number 10 spokesman said: “We have been very clear we recognise that there are significant pressures on the NHS with an ageing and growing population. Read More Cancer patient blasts NHS after vital surgery cancelled TWICE by hospital due to shortage of beds 
“But we have also been very clear that the Government is committed to securing high-quality healthcare for everyone. 
“That’s why we have given the NHS the extra funding it asked for, an additional £10billion by 2020 with a frontloading of £4billion of that in the last financial year.” 
Separate figures for July to September 2016, show 19,399 operations were cancelled for non-clinical reasons. 
The figures come as the Royal College of Surgeons hit out at plans to ration the number of hip and knee replacement operations. Read More 103-year-old woman who split her head open in horror accident had to wait THREE hours for an ambulance 
To qualify for surgery, patients would need to have such severe levels of pain that they cannot sleep or carry out daily tasks. 
Redditch and ­Bromsgrove, South ­Worcestershire, and Wyre Forest clinical commissioning groups have proposed slashing those who qualify by up to 19% – or 350 operations a year – saving £2million. The Royal College of Surgeons said there is “no clinical justification” for the plans. 
But a spokeswoman for Redditch and Bromsgrove CCG said: “If a patient feels that they require this surgery but do not meet these criteria, there is a clear appeals system.” 
Downing Street said these decisions “need to be made by medics”. Like us on Facebook
